Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. To obtain the link:Open...

Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Sure, sometimes the dream is to completely unplug on a getaway, let the emails gather dust, and embrace full holiday mode. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? That's a pretty good feeling too. hashtag#RemoteWorkLife hashtag#WorkFromAnywhere hashtag#FlexibilityAtItsFinest hashtag#ClientLove hashtag#MakingItWork

Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? Here's What Most Freelancers Get Wrong.After 3+ years in the freelance world, managing multiple profiles and generating over $2M+ in Upwork sales, I've seen one thing over and over:Great talent loses out because of poor proposals.Not because theyâ€™re not skilled. Not because the client didnâ€™t like them. But because their bid didnâ€™t connect.Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned actually works when it comes to Upwork bidding:âœ… Customize every proposal. Templates are tempting. But clients know when you're copy-pasting. Personalization goes a long way.âœ… Lead with value. Donâ€™t introduce yourself first. Tell them what problem youâ€™ll solve or how youâ€™ve solved it before.âœ… Keep it short but meaningful. Clients are busy. Get to the point, and make that point strong.âœ… Ask the right questions. A thoughtful question shows you care and helps start a conversation.âœ… Follow up (the right way). If a proposal is strong, a simple follow-up can bring it back to the top of the list.Bidding is a strategy not a numbers game. If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

ğŸ§© Dialogs & Alerts: Compose Dialogs vs XML DialogFragmentsğŸ‘‹ Welcome to Post 8 of my ongoing series comparing Jetpack Compose with traditional XML-based Android development. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Straight from a joyful family celebration to tackling what needed doing.That's the quirky beauty of working from home.Your office travels with you! Sure, sometimes the dream is to completely unplug on a getaway, let the emails gather dust, and embrace full holiday mode. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? That's a pretty good feeling too. hashtag#RemoteWorkLife hashtag#WorkFromAnywhere hashtag#FlexibilityAtItsFinest hashtag#ClientLove hashtag#MakingItWork

Here's What Most Freelancers Get Wrong.After 3+ years in the freelance world, managing multiple profiles and generating over $2M+ in Upwork sales, I've seen one thing over and over:Great talent loses out because of poor proposals.Not because theyâ€™re not skilled. Not because the client didnâ€™t like them. But because their bid didnâ€™t connect.Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned actually works when it comes to Upwork bidding:âœ… Customize every proposal. Templates are tempting. But clients know when you're copy-pasting. Personalization goes a long way.âœ… Lead with value. Donâ€™t introduce yourself first. Tell them what problem youâ€™ll solve or how youâ€™ve solved it before.âœ… Keep it short but meaningful. Clients are busy. Get to the point, and make that point strong.âœ… Ask the right questions. A thoughtful question shows you care and helps start a conversation.âœ… Follow up (the right way). If a proposal is strong, a simple follow-up can bring it back to the top of the list.Bidding is a strategy not a numbers game. Itâ€™s about matching your offer with what the client truly needs, and showing youâ€™re the right fit clearly, confidently, and fast.If youâ€™re stuck sending 20+ proposals a week with little to no response, you might not need more connects  you might need a better strategy.Letâ€™s connect if youâ€™re looking to improve your bidding game, optimize your profile, or simply want to discuss freelance growth strategies. If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

ğŸ§© Dialogs & Alerts: Compose Dialogs vs XML DialogFragmentsğŸ‘‹ Welcome to Post 8 of my ongoing series comparing Jetpack Compose with traditional XML-based Android development. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? Here's What Most Freelancers Get Wrong.After 3+ years in the freelance world, managing multiple profiles and generating over $2M+ in Upwork sales, I've seen one thing over and over:Great talent loses out because of poor proposals.Not because theyâ€™re not skilled. Not because the client didnâ€™t like them. But because their bid didnâ€™t connect.Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned actually works when it comes to Upwork bidding:âœ… Customize every proposal. Templates are tempting. But clients know when you're copy-pasting. Personalization goes a long way.âœ… Lead with value. Donâ€™t introduce yourself first. Tell them what problem youâ€™ll solve or how youâ€™ve solved it before.âœ… Keep it short but meaningful. Clients are busy. Get to the point, and make that point strong.âœ… Ask the right questions. A thoughtful question shows you care and helps start a conversation.âœ… Follow up (the right way). If a proposal is strong, a simple follow-up can bring it back to the top of the list.Bidding is a strategy not a numbers game. Itâ€™s about matching your offer with what the client truly needs, and showing youâ€™re the right fit clearly, confidently, and fast.If youâ€™re stuck sending 20+ proposals a week with little to no response, you might not need more connects  you might need a better strategy.Letâ€™s connect if youâ€™re looking to improve your bidding game, optimize your profile, or simply want to discuss freelance growth strategies. If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

ğŸ§© Dialogs & Alerts: Compose Dialogs vs XML DialogFragmentsğŸ‘‹ Welcome to Post 8 of my ongoing series comparing Jetpack Compose with traditional XML-based Android development. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Here's What Most Freelancers Get Wrong.After 3+ years in the freelance world, managing multiple profiles and generating over $2M+ in Upwork sales, I've seen one thing over and over:Great talent loses out because of poor proposals.Not because theyâ€™re not skilled. If a proposal is strong, a simple follow-up can bring it back to the top of the list.Bidding is a strategy not a numbers game. If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

As a Threat Hunter QRadar UI always attracts me!A couple of years into working in a SOC, I found myself naturally pulled into the world of threat hunting. At the time, I was using QRadar. I genuinely appreciated its UI for hunting: quick filters, group-by views, and an interface that made it easy to explore â€” everything right there on the screen. It was intuitive, especially from an analystâ€™s perspective.But there was a challenge.While QRadar is built on a structured Ariel database, it often felt restrictive when hunting required flexibility across diverse log types. The schema-based nature and normalization process introduced friction for more dynamic, free-form queries. As hunting got deeper, the platform felt heavier.That challenge stayed with me.Years later, while designing the Threat Hunting module for SOCByte, I kept that experience front and center: 1- The UI should feel familiar and fast â€” like QRadar at its best. 2- But the backend should on Elasticsearch, allowing scalable and flexibility.The result? An experience where power and simplicity meet â€” making threat hunting not just possible, but actually enjoyable.Iâ€™m curious â€” whatâ€™s been your experience with threat hunting in different SIEMs? What did you like, and where did you hit friction?

ğŸ§© Dialogs & Alerts: Compose Dialogs vs XML DialogFragmentsğŸ‘‹ Welcome to Post 8 of my ongoing series comparing Jetpack Compose with traditional XML-based Android development. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Straight from a joyful family celebration to tackling what needed doing.That's the quirky beauty of working from home.Your office travels with you! Sure, sometimes the dream is to completely unplug on a getaway, let the emails gather dust, and embrace full holiday mode. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? That's a pretty good feeling too. hashtag#RemoteWorkLife hashtag#WorkFromAnywhere hashtag#FlexibilityAtItsFinest hashtag#ClientLove hashtag#MakingItWork

If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

As a Threat Hunter QRadar UI always attracts me!A couple of years into working in a SOC, I found myself naturally pulled into the world of threat hunting. At the time, I was using QRadar. I genuinely appreciated its UI for hunting: quick filters, group-by views, and an interface that made it easy to explore â€” everything right there on the screen. It was intuitive, especially from an analystâ€™s perspective.But there was a challenge.While QRadar is built on a structured Ariel database, it often felt restrictive when hunting required flexibility across diverse log types. The schema-based nature and normalization process introduced friction for more dynamic, free-form queries. As hunting got deeper, the platform felt heavier.That challenge stayed with me.Years later, while designing the Threat Hunting module for SOCByte, I kept that experience front and center: 1- The UI should feel familiar and fast â€” like QRadar at its best. 2- But the backend should on Elasticsearch, allowing scalable and flexibility.The result? An experience where power and simplicity meet â€” making threat hunting not just possible, but actually enjoyable.Iâ€™m curious â€” whatâ€™s been your experience with threat hunting in different SIEMs? What did you like, and where did you hit friction?

Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

As a Threat Hunter QRadar UI always attracts me!A couple of years into working in a SOC, I found myself naturally pulled into the world of threat hunting. At the time, I was using QRadar. I genuinely appreciated its UI for hunting: quick filters, group-by views, and an interface that made it easy to explore â€” everything right there on the screen. It was intuitive, especially from an analystâ€™s perspective.But there was a challenge.While QRadar is built on a structured Ariel database, it often felt restrictive when hunting required flexibility across diverse log types. The schema-based nature and normalization process introduced friction for more dynamic, free-form queries. As hunting got deeper, the platform felt heavier.That challenge stayed with me.Years later, while designing the Threat Hunting module for SOCByte, I kept that experience front and center: 1- The UI should feel familiar and fast â€” like QRadar at its best. 2- But the backend should on Elasticsearch, allowing scalable and flexibility.The result? An experience where power and simplicity meet â€” making threat hunting not just possible, but actually enjoyable.Iâ€™m curious â€” whatâ€™s been your experience with threat hunting in different SIEMs? What did you like, and where did you hit friction?

If your .env file is still showing up in your PR  on GitHub even though you have added  .env in your .gitignore file, then it's likely that the file(.env) was already tracked by Git before being ignored.This simply means that Git still has the .env file tracked from your previous commits before it was added to the .gitignore file. The "persistence" of the .env file in subsequent commits is  because by design , Git doesnâ€™t automatically untrack files after adding them to .gitignore. It only prevents new files from being tracked.To get this issue resolved, you need to manually untrack the .env file by running the commands in the image below:hashtag#Githashtag#Developershashtag#Github

ğŸ§© Dialogs & Alerts: Compose Dialogs vs XML DialogFragmentsğŸ‘‹ Welcome to Post 8 of my ongoing series comparing Jetpack Compose with traditional XML-based Android development. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? How are you balancing legacy protocols with modern network needs?Letâ€™s talk tech that actually works in production.In Arabic: â¬…ï¸ Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate:ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ù…Ù„ÙŠØ¡ Ø¨ØªÙ‚Ù†ÙŠØ§Øª SD-WAN ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø¨ÙƒØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙƒØ²Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø­Ø§Ø¨Ø©ØŒ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‡Ù„ Ø£Ù† Ù†ØªØºØ§Ø¶Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø±ÙˆØªÙˆÙƒÙˆÙ„Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‚Ù„ÙŠØ¯ÙŠØ© Ù…Ø«Ù„ OSPF. Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? If you're a Developer, you will need this text editor!I have been exploring Cursor AI. A text editor developed on top of VS Code. It generally uses AI models such as Claude. ai, chatGPT, and other AI models. So, I decided to create a simple to-do app using Laravel and TailwindCSS. And of course, I used whatâ€™s now called "vibe coding".What's Vibe Coding anyway? they say it's a way of letting the AI write the entire code for you. Your work is to prompt it using natural language.My suggestion? We are not there. Why? As I vibe-coded, we kept going back and forth until I landed on something solid.You can't rely 100% on the code it generates. For example, I used Laravel 12, the new version of the framework. However, it doesn't know what's new. Most of the time, it brings in old Laravel syntax. Another suggestion? You need to know what you're doing!!!.The following is what I came up with. Any comment? Post it below. Happy coding!hashtag#laravel hashtag#tailwindcss hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#AI hashtag#softwaredev

As a Threat Hunter QRadar UI always attracts me!A couple of years into working in a SOC, I found myself naturally pulled into the world of threat hunting. At the time, I was using QRadar. I genuinely appreciated its UI for hunting: quick filters, group-by views, and an interface that made it easy to explore â€” everything right there on the screen. It was intuitive, especially from an analystâ€™s perspective.But there was a challenge.While QRadar is built on a structured Ariel database, it often felt restrictive when hunting required flexibility across diverse log types. The schema-based nature and normalization process introduced friction for more dynamic, free-form queries. As hunting got deeper, the platform felt heavier.That challenge stayed with me.Years later, while designing the Threat Hunting module for SOCByte, I kept that experience front and center: 1- The UI should feel familiar and fast â€” like QRadar at its best. 2- But the backend should on Elasticsearch, allowing scalable and flexibility.The result? An experience where power and simplicity meet â€” making threat hunting not just possible, but actually enjoyable.Iâ€™m curious â€” whatâ€™s been your experience with threat hunting in different SIEMs? What did you like, and where did you hit friction?

If your .env file is still showing up in your PR  on GitHub even though you have added  .env in your .gitignore file, then it's likely that the file(.env) was already tracked by Git before being ignored.This simply means that Git still has the .env file tracked from your previous commits before it was added to the .gitignore file. The "persistence" of the .env file in subsequent commits is  because by design , Git doesnâ€™t automatically untrack files after adding them to .gitignore. Todayâ€™s focus is: Creating Dialogs and Alerts.ğŸ§± XML DialogFragmentsIn traditional Android (XML-based), dialogs are created using DialogFragment or AlertDialog.Builder.ğŸ”¸ Example:AlertDialog.Builder(context) .setTitle("Title") .setMessage("Message") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .setNegativeButton("Cancel", null) .create() .show()âœ… ProsFull-featuredCan survive config changes (with DialogFragment)Lifecycle-awareâŒ ConsVerboseRequires FragmentManagerMore boilerplateComplex for simple use casesğŸ”¸ Jetpack Compose DialogsIn Compose, you can use AlertDialog() composable or even build custom dialogs using Dialog {}.ğŸ”¸ Example:if (showDialog) { AlertDialog( onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false }, title = { Text("Title") }, text = { Text("Message") }, confirmButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("OK") } }, dismissButton = { Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) { Text("Cancel") } } )}âœ… ProsMinimal boilerplateBuilt into the UI treeDeclarative, lifecycle-safeEasy customizationâŒ ConsNo back stack persistenceManual state handlingNeeds custom logic for complex usehashtag#JetpackCompose hashtag#AndroidDevelopment hashtag#ComposeVsXML hashtag#DialogFragment hashtag#ComposeDialog hashtag#AndroidUI hashtag#MobileDevelopment hashtag#Kotlin hashtag#UIUX hashtag#AndroidTips hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#ComposeSeries

Integrate Figma with Cursor IDE to Build a Web Login Page hashtag#FigmaIntegration hashtag#CursorIDE hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AIProductivity hashtag#LoginPageDesignhttps://lnkd.in/dns6tUPT Integrating Figma with Cursor IDE for Web DevelopmentIntegrating Figma with Cursor IDE Using an MCP Server to Build a Web Login PageIntroductionIntegrating design tools like Figma with development environments such as Cursor IDE can significantly enhance productivity. By utilizing the Model Context Protocol (MCP), developers can streamline the process of creating web pages directly from design files. This guide provides a straightforward approach to set up this integration and build a simple login page using Cursor IDE.Step 1: Setting Up the EnvironmentObtaining the Figma API TokenLog in to your Figma account.Navigate to Settings > Security and select Generate new token.Name your token and ensure you have read permissions on File content and Dev resources, then click Generate token.Copy and store the token securely for future use.Installing NTo run the Figma MCP server, you will need to install N:Download the latest version of N from the official website.Run the installer and keep default settings during installation.Verify the installation by running the following commands in your terminal:node -v â€“ should return the N versionnpm -v â€“ should return the npm versionnpx -v â€“ should return the npx versionInstalling Cursor IDEDownload Cursor IDE, which is free and offers a 14-day trial. Cursor is specifically designed for AI-assisted development and will facilitate the connection to the Figma MCP server.Step 2: Configuring MCP Server on CursorAfter installing Cursor IDE, follow these steps to connect to your Figma MCP server:Open Cursor IDE and navigate to File > Preferences > Cursor Settings > MCP.Select Add a new global MCP server.In the configuration file, paste the following code: "mcpServers": { "Framelink Figma MCP": { "command": "cmd", "args": ["/c", "npx", "-y", "figma-developer-mcp", "--figma-api-key=YOUR-KEY", "--stdio"] } }Replace YOUR-KEY with the Figma API token you generated earlier.Save the configuration file. You should now see â€œFramelink Figma MCPâ€ listed under available MCP servers.Close the settings pane and start using the server by entering relevant prompts in Cursorâ€™s chat interface. This will allow you to connect to your Figma file and generate code accordingly.Step 3: Creating the Login Page Using Cursor AIUsing a Figma template, I instructed Cursorâ€™s chat agent to generate both an HTML and a CSS file for a login page. Additionally, I requested modifications, such as updating footer text and adding animations, which Cursor executed seamlessly.For your projects, use any Figma design by copying the frame URL and providing it to Cursor. Straight from a joyful family celebration to tackling what needed doing.That's the quirky beauty of working from home.Your office travels with you! Sure, sometimes the dream is to completely unplug on a getaway, let the emails gather dust, and embrace full holiday mode. But hey, flexibility is our superpower, and knowing you can be there when needed? That's a pretty good feeling too. hashtag#RemoteWorkLife hashtag#WorkFromAnywhere hashtag#FlexibilityAtItsFinest hashtag#ClientLove hashtag#MakingItWork
